texts.label: text
texts.orig: This error completely stumped me a couple of weeks ago. Apparently someone was adjusting the Apache configuration, then they checked their syntax and attempted to restart Apache. It went down without a problem, but it refused to start properly, and didn't bind to any ports.
texts.text: This error completely stumped me a couple of weeks ago. Apparently someone was adjusting the Apache configuration, then they checked their syntax and attempted to restart Apache. It went down without a problem, but it refused to start properly, and didn't bind to any ports.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Within the Apache error logs, this message appeared over and over:
texts.text: Within the Apache error logs, this message appeared over and over:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: [emerg] (28)No space left on device: Couldn't create accept lock
texts.text: [emerg] (28)No space left on device: Couldn't create accept lock

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Apache is basically saying “I want to start, but I need to write some things down before I can start, and I have nowhere to write them!” If this happens to you, check these items in order:
texts.text: Apache is basically saying “I want to start, but I need to write some things down before I can start, and I have nowhere to write them!” If this happens to you, check these items in order:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: This comes first because it's the easiest to check, and sometimes the quickest to fix. If you're out of disk space, then you need to fix that problem. :-)
texts.text: This comes first because it's the easiest to check, and sometimes the quickest to fix. If you're out of disk space, then you need to fix that problem. :-)

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If your filesystem uses quotas, you might be reaching a quota limit rather than a disk space limit. Use
texts.text: If your filesystem uses quotas, you might be reaching a quota limit rather than a disk space limit. Use

texts.label: text
texts.orig: to review your quotas on the root partition. If you're at the limit, raise your quota or clear up some disk space. Apache logs are usually the culprit in these situations.
texts.text: to review your quotas on the root partition. If you're at the limit, raise your quota or clear up some disk space. Apache logs are usually the culprit in these situations.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Semaphores? What the heck is a semaphore? Well, it's actually an  apparatus for conveying information by means of visual signals . But, when it comes to programming,  semaphores are used for communicating between the active processes of a certain application . In the case of Apache, they're used to communicate between the parent and child processes. If Apache can't write these things down, then it can't communicate properly with all of the processes it starts.
texts.text: Semaphores? What the heck is a semaphore? Well, it's actually an  apparatus for conveying information by means of visual signals . But, when it comes to programming,  semaphores are used for communicating between the active processes of a certain application . In the case of Apache, they're used to communicate between the parent and child processes. If Apache can't write these things down, then it can't communicate properly with all of the processes it starts.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: I'd assume if you're reading this article, Apache has stopped running. Run this command as root:
texts.text: I'd assume if you're reading this article, Apache has stopped running. Run this command as root:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you see a list of semaphores, Apache has not cleaned up after itself, and some semaphores are stuck. Clear them out with this command:
texts.text: If you see a list of semaphores, Apache has not cleaned up after itself, and some semaphores are stuck. Clear them out with this command:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: # for i in `ipcs -s | awk '/httpd/ {print $2}'`; do (ipcrm -s $i); done
texts.text: # for i in `ipcs -s | awk '/httpd/ {print $2}'`; do (ipcrm -s $i); done

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Now, in almost all cases, Apache should start properly. If it doesn't, you may just be completely out of available semaphores. You may want to increase your available semaphores, and you'll need to tickle your kernel to do so. Add this to /etc/sysctl.conf:
texts.text: Now, in almost all cases, Apache should start properly. If it doesn't, you may just be completely out of available semaphores. You may want to increase your available semaphores, and you'll need to tickle your kernel to do so. Add this to /etc/sysctl.conf:

texts.orig: to pick up the new changes.
texts.text: to pick up the new changes.
